dt: {bc}to make use of (someone or something inactive)
{bc}to use or engage the services of
{bc}to provide with a job that pays wages or a salary
{bc}to devote to or direct toward a particular activity or person

dt.t: {wi}employed{/wi} all her energies to help the poor

pt: {sc}use{/sc} {sc}employ{/sc} {sc}utilize{/sc} mean to put into service especially to attain an end. {sc}use{/sc} implies availing oneself of something as a means or instrument to an end.

pt.t: willing to {it}use{/it} any means to achieve her ends

pt: {sc}employ{/sc} suggests the use of a person or thing that is available but idle, inactive, or disengaged.

pt.t: looking for better ways to {it}employ{/it} their skills

pt: {sc}utilize{/sc} may suggest the discovery of a new, profitable, or practical use for something.

pt.t: an old wooden bucket {it}utilized{/it} as a planter

et: Middle English {it}emploien{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}empleier, emploier, emplier{/it} to entangle, apply, make use of, from Latin {it}implicare{/it} to enfold, involve, from {it}in-{/it} + {it}plicare{/it} to fold {ma}{mat|ply|}{/ma}
shortdef: to make use of (someone or something inactive)
to use (something, such as time) advantageously
to use or engage the services of

utxt.t: … would say only that [he] resigned due to medical issues, and that he has not sought {wi}reemployment{/wi} with the village.
These amazing {wi}reemployments{/wi} of men who had been drummed out of the service only a year or two earlier …
